pullRequest.body:
We add various version of the circuit elimination axiom, and some lemmas about finitary matroids. 

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [8136a4e8eb](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/21172/commits/8136a4e8ebef8f7a8d60ec4dc1dbaf5805a13f35)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Circuit.elimination`
`+ Circuit.finite`
`+ Circuit.strong_elimination`
`+ Circuit.strong_multi_elimination`
`+ Circuit.strong_multi_elimination_set`
`+ exists_circuit_of_mem_closure`
`+ exists_mem_finite_closure_of_mem_closure`
`+ exists_subset_finite_closure_of_subset_closure`
`+ finitary_iff_forall_circuit_finite`
`+ mem_closure_iff_exists_circuit`
`+ strong_multi_elimination_insert`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
The name `h_not_mem` is weird.

I'd rather not see explicit arguments in `variable` hiding from the actual declarations.
Also the names `Is Cs` are not idiomatic for functions.
Can `x` be implicit?
It can, but I think it is more common to explicitly specify it in use cases.
In this case, I strongly prefer it to appear with individual declarations.

It is increasingly more common (but not 100% required) for explicit arguments to be avoided in `variable` declarations, for ease of reading. In this case, I think that rule of thumb is sensible: certainly the first point of confusion I had when reading the strong elimination lemmas was "where did this `x` thing come from?", particularly because `C0` and `C` are written there.

```suggestion
  hC.subset_closure_diff_singleton e heC
```
Actually now that I look at it more closely, since this is just a combination of `heC` with `Circuit.subset_closure_diff_singleton`, does this lemma need to exist?
I would keep it.
It gets a bit of use in the repo, and its use reduces defeq abuse by epsilon, so I prefer to have it around.
I'm not quite certain epsilon is nonzero here, but let's go with it for now!

```suggestion
    (hC : ∀ i, M.Circuit (C i)) (h_mem_C₀ : ∀ i, x i ∈ C₀) (h_mem : ∀ i, x i ∈ C i)
```

```suggestion
/-- The circuit elimination axiom: for any pair of distinct circuits `C₁, C₂` and any `e`, some
```

If I'm reading this correctly, it's a finite set `X` spanned by `Y` being spanned by a subset of `Y`?

As an aside, as someone who doesn't know this theory well but is interested in it, I find docstrings like these incredibly valuable!
Thanks for spotting that!

Is it possible to describe in words what the statement is saying here? `C` is the infinite collection of circuits, I guess, but it's not clear to me what the role of `C₀` is (informally speaking). Can we also do the same for `strong_multi_elimination_insert`? (For instance, are `I` and `C` playing the same role?)

```suggestion
lemma Circuit.strong_multi_elimination_insert (I : ι → Set α) (hxI : ∀ i, x i ∉ I i) {J : Set α}
```
for consistency with the next one
The difference is the dot notation, since the `Circuit` hypothesis is more indirect here, but is a natural first argument in the other lemma. Do you think it's still a good idea?
I agree with @apnelson1 here.

I do still think it's a good idea. I agree that the value of dot notation here is diminished, but the benefits are still there:
- the family of elimination lemmas all have similar names, which aids understanding when reading the docs
- when searching or using vscode completion, the substring "Circuit" still shows up
I am on the side of having a better dot notation.

This version of the statement is for an indexed family of circuits, is it useful to also have a set family version? That is, `C : Set (Set α)` such that everything in `C` is a circuit. (If so, it doesn't need to be in this PR)
This is a little tricky, because the `x i` are tied to the circuits `C i` via `h_unique`.
I see, that makes sense. Would it work to say we have a set of `x`, and each one is in a unique circuit?
Let me try!

Ok, I've made a working version, and it's clean enough to include. (The equals singleton hypothesis is a little awkward, but I don't think it can be stated with just `∃!`, since you need to forbid two different `x` corresponding to the same circuit.)
Nice! It turned out well!

```suggestion
  replace hC : ∀ (i : ι), M.closure (I i) = M.closure ({x i} ∪ (I i)) := by 
    simpa [diff_singleton_eq_self (hxI _)] using fun i ↦ (hC i).closure_diff_singleton_eq (x i)
```
In this one, you might also consider moving `i` before the colon (and the `using` clause might be simplifiable after that).

```suggestion
  replace hC := show ∀ (i : ι), M.closure (I i) = M.closure (insert (x i) (I i))
```
I'd expect this one is slightly easier to work with (although I don't know if the closure_insert lemma that you want here exists already). If not, then `({x i} ∪ I i)` would be nice instead
It's because there is no distributivity lemma for insertion and iUnions. This felt out of scope, and the workaround wasn't so bad here.
Hmm, I see. I agree it's out of scope, but I feel a solution which is better for mathlib overall would be to have a different PR which adds the missing distributivity lemma, then use that lemma here
The `(z := f)` here suggests that maybe it should be explicit in `strong_multi_elimination`?

```suggestion
lemma mem_closure_iff_exists_circuit (he : e ∉ X) :
```
I think this is clear enough. More importantly though, let's keep the name of this and the name of `exists_circuit_of_mem_closure` consistent: either both should have `of_not_mem`, or neither.

pullRequest.title: feat(Data/Matroid/Circuit): circuit elimination and finitary matroids
